ref_text: Appropriate use of blogs "can empower students to become more analytical and critical; through actively responding to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of others' writings as well as outline their own perspectives on particular issues (Oravec, 2002).
hyp_text: The ability to write well and effectively is a key skill for school students. It is a skill that will enable students to respond clearly and intelligently to texts of all kinds, to develop their own ideas in a logical and well-organized way, and to communicate their thoughts and feelings to others. It is also a skill that will help students in their studies and in their future working lives. Writing well is not just a matter of having a good vocabulary or being able to use correct grammar. It is also a matter of having a clear and logical way of thinking, and of being able to express one’s thoughts and feelings in a clear and effective way. In order to write well, students need to be able to think clearly and logically, and to be able to express their thoughts and feelings in a clear and effective way. They also need to be able to write in a variety of styles, depending on the purpose and audience of their writing. There are a number of different ways to approach writing, and no one method is right for everyone. However, there are some general principles that all good writers follow. These principles include: 1. Planning: Good writers plan their writing before they start. They think about what they want to say, and how they want to say it. They also think about their audience, and what they want to achieve with their writing. 2. Drafting: Good writers don’t try to write perfect first drafts. They know that it’s impossible to get everything right the first time. They are willing to make mistakes, and to revise and edit their work until it is as good as it can be. 3. Revising: Good writers revise their work. They look for ways to make their writing clearer, more concise, and more effective. They also look for ways to improve their grammar, punctuation, and spelling. 4. Editing: Good writers edit their work. They check for errors in grammar, punctuation, and spelling. They also check for clarity, conciseness, and effectiveness. 5. Proofreading: Good writers proofread their work. They check for errors in grammar, punctuation, and spelling. They also check for clarity, conciseness, and effectiveness. 6. Publishing: Good writers publish their work. They share their writing with others, and they seek feedback from their readers. 7. Reflecting: Good writers reflect on their writing. They think about what they have written, and how they can improve it. They also think about how their writing can be used to achieve their goals. 8. Enjoying: Good writers enjoy their writing. They find pleasure in the act of writing, and in the process of creating something new. 9. Sharing: Good writers share their writing. They share their work with others, and they seek feedback from their readers. 10. Learning: Good writers are always learning. They are always looking for new ways to improve their writing, and they are always willing to try new things. Writing well is a skill that can be learned. It is a skill that can be developed through practice and hard work. It is also a skill that can be improved with feedback and guidance from others. If you are a student, or if you are someone who wants to improve your writing skills, there are a number of things you can do. You can take a writing course, or you can join a writing group. You can also read books and articles about writing, and you can practice writing on your own. The most important thing is to keep writing, and to keep learning. With time and practice, you will become a better writer.

hyp_text: The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) is a multilateral treaty. The Convention has three main goals: the conservation of biological diversity (or biodiversity); the sustainable use of its components; and the fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from genetic resources. In other words, its objective is to develop national strategies for the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity. It is often seen as the key document regarding sustainable development. The Convention was opened for signature at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro on 5 June 1992 and entered into force on 29 December 1993. It has two supplementary agreements, the Cartagena Protocol and Nagoya Protocol. The Cartagena Protocol, which became effective on 11 September 2003, was adopted to prevent the spread of potentially harmful genetically modified organisms. The Nagoya Protocol aims at sharing the benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources in a fair and equitable way, including by appropriate access to genetic resources and by appropriate transfer of relevant technologies. It entered into force on 12 October 2014.
